Title: A Randomised Controlled Trial Comparing Robotic-Assisted and Hand-Rasped Techniques in Total Hip Arthroplasty

Background: This randomised controlled trial aimed to compare the long-term outcomes of robotic-assisted versus hand-rasped femoral component insertion in total hip arthroplasty (THA).

Methods: The trial was conducted at two institutions with five experienced surgeons. Participants included 130 patients eligible for primary cementless THA, randomized to either robotic-assisted (75 hips, 69 patients) or hand-rasped (71 hips, 61 patients) groups. Randomisation was performed using a computer-generated sequence with allocation concealment. The primary outcome was the Japanese Orthopaedic Association (JOA) score, measured at a minimum follow-up of 10 years. Secondary outcomes included revision surgery, aseptic loosening, and heterotopic ossification. Blinding was applied to outcome assessors.

Results: At a mean follow-up of 135 months, 115 patients (88%) were available for analysis. JOA scores showed no significant difference between groups (robotic: 97 ± 5, hand-rasped: 96 ± 7; mean difference 1.4; p = 0.159). No aseptic loosening or revisions occurred in either group. Heterotopic ossification was observed in 30% of the robotic group and 19% of the hand-rasped group (p = 0.186), with no Grade 4 cases.

Interpretation: Robotic-assisted THA did not demonstrate superior clinical or radiographic outcomes compared to hand-rasped techniques over 10 years. The findings do not support the widespread adoption of robotic milling for stem implantation in primary cementless THAs.
